code:
#!/usr/bin/env python

import httplib
c = httplib.HTTPSConnection("ccc.de")
c.request("GET", "/")
response = c.getresponse()
print response.status, response.reason
data = response.read()
print data
# => 
# 200 OK
# <!DOCTYPE html ....

text: To verify if SSL is enabled, try:
It doesn't do SSL validation but this isn't required to connect over https.
Your code works fine with https connection:

code:
>>> import httplib
>>> conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection("mail.google.com")
>>> conn.request("GET", "/")
>>> r1 = conn.getresponse()
>>> print r1.status, r1.reason
200 OK

text: Assuming SSL support is enabled for the socket module.
To check for ssl support in Python 2.6+:

code:
try:
    import ssl
except ImportError:
    print "error: no ssl support"

import urllib2

try:
    response = urllib2.urlopen('https://example.com') 
    print 'response headers: "%s"' % response.info()
except IOError, e:
    if hasattr(e, 'code'): # HTTPError
        print 'http error code: ', e.code
    elif hasattr(e, 'reason'): # URLError
        print "can't connect, reason: ", e.reason
    else:
        raise

text: For 2.x take a look at http://bugs.python.org/issue3466
